proof: Proof. We have $|c/\alpha|_1 \le k$ and $|c/\alpha|_\infty \le 1$. It is well known that $c/\alpha$ is a convex combination of $\{0,1\}$-vectors. Since $|c/\alpha|_1 \le k$, the support of this convex combination can be restricted to vectors with exactly $k$ 1's. For each $\{0,1\}$-vector $d$ in this restricted combination, we have $\sum_{r \in V} d(r)\text{cost}_C(r) \le \text{cost}_C^k$. Taking the convex combination of these inequalities gives $\sum_{r \in V} \frac{c(r)}{\alpha}\text{cost}_C(r) \le \text{cost}_C^k$, which is equivalent to the inequality in the claim.
